tag: U3 p32 GR2 Present perfect vs past simple
questionText: [markdown]Match the phrases in bold in the following sentences to the respective tense and use. {

associations.left: =You can see she**'s been swimming** – her hair's still wet.
associations.right: Present perfect continuous - for a recent completed activity when the effects are still relevant
Past simple - for a state in the past

associations.left: =Carol**'s been working** here for the last few weeks while Chloe's away having a baby.
associations.right: Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is temporary

associations.left: =I**'ve only worn** that shirt three times since I bought it.
associations.right: Present perfect - for an action repeated up to the present time

associations.left: =I**'ve been having** driving lessons for months but I'm not getting any better.
associations.right: Present perfect continuous - to emphasise that an action has been going on for a long time

associations.left: =All my friends at school **played** football, not rugby.
associations.right: Past simple - for a habit in the past

associations.left: =Harry's birthday party **didn't end** until three in the morning.
associations.right: Past simple - for a finished event that happened at a specific time in the past

associations.left: =They**'ve been building** that house for ages and it's still only half-finished.
associations.right: Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is not complete

reponses: =You can see she**'s been swimming** – her hair's still wet.                            -> Present perfect continuous - for a recent completed activity when the effects are still relevant
=I **knew** almost everyone at the party.                                               -> Past simple - for a state in the past
=Carol**'s been working** here for the last few weeks while Chloe's away having a baby. -> Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is temporary
=I**'ve only worn** that shirt three times since I bought it.                           -> Present perfect - for an action repeated up to the present time
=I**'ve been having** driving lessons for months but I'm not getting any better.        -> Present perfect continuous - to emphasise that an action has been going on for a long time
=All my friends at school **played** football, not rugby.                               -> Past simple - for a habit in the past
=Harry's birthday party **didn't end** until three in the morning.                      -> Past simple - for a finished event that happened at a specific time in the past
=They**'ve been building** that house for ages and it's still only half-finished.       -> Present perfect continuous - to suggest that an activity is not complete

questionText: Complete the sentences with the correct form of the word in brackets (you might need to use the negative form).
Match the fragments to make sentences. {

associations.left: =I always put my foot in it when I’m nervous and
=His explanation is rather far-fetched, which means
associations.right: I find it difficult to believe.

associations.left: =I can never keep a straight face so
=I’m getting cold feet about the cycling race because
associations.right: I don’t think I’ve trained enough.

associations.left: =If I’m told there will be side effects,
associations.right: I prefer to avoid taking it.

associations.left: =Tom and I don’t see eye to eye about many issues so
associations.right: I can’t see our relationship lasting.

associations.left: =My parents want me to keep an eye on my brother so
associations.right: I won’t be able to go out tonight.

associations.left: =If something in a shop window catches my eye,
associations.right: I can’t resist going in to look at it.

reponses: =I always put my foot in it when I’m nervous and      -> I say really embarrassing things.
=His explanation is rather far-fetched, which means   -> I find it difficult to believe.
=I can never keep a straight face so                  -> I’m useless at telling jokes.
=I’m getting cold feet about the cycling race because -> I don’t think I’ve trained enough.
=If I’m told there will be side effects,              -> I prefer to avoid taking it.
=Tom and I don’t see eye to eye about many issues so  -> I can’t see our relationship lasting.
=My parents want me to keep an eye on my brother so   -> I won’t be able to go out tonight.
=If something in a shop window catches my eye,        -> I can’t resist going in to look at it.

Match the uses of future forms to the examples. {

associations.left: =will (a decision made at the moment of speaking)
associations.right: I'll call Graham now, shall I?

associations.left: =going to (an opinion based on present evidence)
associations.right: She's gone very pale – she's going to faint.
I'm going to apply to university next year.
They're getting married sometime next year.
The conference is in the first week of April.

associations.left: =Present simple (a time clause with a future meaning)
associations.right: When you arrive at the airport, phone me.

reponses: =will (an expert opinion) -> The road will be closed.
=will (a decision made at the moment of speaking) -> I'll call Graham now, shall I?
=going to (an opinion based on present evidence) -> She's gone very pale – she's going to faint.
=going to (a personal intention) -> I'm going to apply to university next year.
=Present continuous (a planned event)                    -> They're getting married sometime next year.
=Present simple (a timetabled event)                     -> The conference is in the first week of April.
=Present simple (a time clause with a future meaning)    -> When you arrive at the airport, phone me.

tag: U6 p62 Reading - Text: Sharing the self love
questionText: Sharing the (self) love: the rise of the selfie and digital narcissism
Complete this sentence to summarise the writer’s main point.
reponses: ~get a false impression of the celebrities they follow.
~have unrealistic hopes for their own futures.
~=become too focused on the opinion others have of them.

questionText: For the gaps in the text (1-6), choose the sentence that fits each gap. There is one extra sentence which you do not need to use. {

associations.right: Then came reality TV, which turned the attention back to ourselves.
Interestingly, what they all seem to have in common is digital attention seeking.
Such increases pre-date social media but they have clearly worsened since its arrival.

The explanation for this is that narcissistic individuals are much more likely to use social media to portray an enviable, if unrealistic, self-image, broadcasting their life to an audience and gaining many virtual friends.
Furthermore, the need to be appreciated is a crucial part of psychological wellbeing, unless it is taken too far and becomes a nonstop search to be valued by others.
New ‘self-help’ mathematical formulas could be built into Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
However, the danger is when these efforts to compensate are supported and rewarded by others.

reponses: =1 -> Then came reality TV, which turned the attention back to ourselves.
=2 -> Interestingly, what they all seem to have in common is digital attention seeking.
=3 -> Such increases pre-date social media but they have clearly worsened since its arrival.

=4 -> The explanation for this is that narcissistic individuals are much more likely to use social media to portray an enviable, if unrealistic, self-image, broadcasting their life to an audience and gaining many virtual friends.
=5 -> Furthermore, the need to be appreciated is a crucial part of psychological wellbeing, unless it is taken too far and becomes a nonstop search to be valued by others.
=6 -> New ‘self-help’ mathematical formulas could be built into Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
=-> However, the danger is when these efforts to compensate are supported and rewarded by others.
